quotes: Amr Moussa... was the Secretary-General of the Arab League... from 1 June 2001 to 1 July 2011.
Minister of Foreign Affairs in office 20 May 1991 – 15 May 2001
Egyptian Ambassador to the United Nations in office 1 January 1990 – 20 May 1991
Born Amr Mouhammed Moussa Abu-Zeid (1936-10-03) 3 October 1936
On 8 September 2013, he was elected president of the committee of 50 that will amend the Egyptian constitution.
Moussa finished his education after earning a degree in law from Cairo University in 1957.
between 1958 and 1972 he worked in several missions, including Egypt's Embassy in Switzerland and the Egyptian mission to the United Nations.
From 1974 to 1977, he was an advisor to the Minister of Foreign Affairs.

time_markers.text: From 1977 to 1981 and again from 1983 to 1990
quotes: From 1977 to 1981 and again from 1983 to 1990, he was the Director of the Department of International Organizations at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
From 1981 to 1983, Moussa was the Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations in New York,
then from 1983 to 1986 Ambassador to India.
In 1990, he was promoted Permanent Representative of Egypt to the United Nations.
He was named Minister of Foreign Affairs by Prime Minister Atef Sedki on 20 May 1991.
He was minister until 15 May 2001 when he was elected as Secretary-General of the Arab League.
Moussa has been heavily involved with Egypt's foreign policy since 1958.
Moussa was Egypt's ambassador to the United Nations, India, and Switzerland for a total of 21 years.
Moussa was one of the Arab and international diplomats who tried to resolve the Lebanese Civil War (1975–1990).
After serving as Egypt's Foreign Minister from 1991 to 2001, he served as the Secretary General of the Arab League.
In August 1994, Moussa made his first official visit to Israel—a visit marked by tension and controversy.
At the Forum for new diplomacy in February 2010, Moussa gave a speech in which he criticized the U.S. government's double standard supporting Israel's nuclear weapons policy
On 15 May 2001, Moussa was selected as Secretary-General of the League of Arab States and took office on 1 June 2001.
On 15 May 2001, Moussa was selected as Secretary-General of the League of Arab States and took office on 1 June 2001.
On 2003, he became a member of the United Nations High Level Panel on Threats, Challenges and Change for International Peace and Security.
Amr Moussa with Giorgio Napolitano, President of Italy (Cairo, 27 October 2008).

On 2009, he signed a memorandum of understanding with the Holy See and met with Pope Benedict XVI in order to strengthen joint projects and to promote peace and dialogue on a cultural and political level.
On 13 June 2010, Moussa visited Gaza in a move to pressure Israel to lift its economic blockade over Hamas-ruled Gaza.
The visit by Moussa was the first by an official of the Arab League since the election of Hamas in 2007.
On 15 May 2011, Nabil Elaraby was elected as Secretary-General of the Arab League and succeeded Moussa on 1 July 2011.
On 15 May 2011, Nabil Elaraby was elected as Secretary-General of the Arab League and succeeded Moussa on 1 July 2011.
In 2004, an online community gathered tens of thousands of signatures petitioning for Moussa to run in the 2005 elections, but there was no response.

Critics of former-President Hosni Mubarak allege that Moussa's appointment to the office of Secretary-General of the Arab League was motivated by Mubarak's desire to remove him from the public spotlight, and so he would not compete as a candidate in the 2005 presidential elections.
Amr Moussa with Vladimir Putin (Cairo, 27 April 2005).
When asked in October 2009 about rumours that he might run for the presidency in 2012, Moussa did not deny his intention to run for office or rule it out, leaving the door open to speculations.
Amr Moussa with William Hague (London, 25 May 2010).
On 26 January 2011, at the Annual Horasis meeting in Zürich, Moussa shared strong views on the need for economic and political reforms in Egypt, and made it clear that he was considering a run.

On 1 February 2011, following the announcement by President Hosni Mubarak that he would not stand in the upcoming presidential elections, Moussa told CNN that he would seriously think about standing himself as a candidate in the next few weeks.

On the 8 February broadcast of Al Jazeera English's Empire, well-connected American journalist Seymour Hersh stated that Moussa was considered the U.S.'s favored 'Plan B' should Mubarak resign, 'whether he knows it or not.'

On 11 February 2011, Al Jazeera English Online read from a Reuters report that stated Moussa was resigning from his position with the Arab League; on the day that President Mubarak resigned the presidency this furthered rumours he might make a strong bid for president when elections are announced in Egypt.
February 2011, the Egyptian daily newspaper Alwafd reported that a group of Egyptian youth met with Moussa to discuss a possible nomination for the presidential election.
Amr Moussa announced that he would be running as a presidential candidate on 1 March 2011.

Previously he served in the government of Egypt as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1991 to 2001.

Moussa has been heavily involved with Egypt's foreign policy since 1958.
between 1958 and 1972 he worked in several missions, including Egypt's Embassy in Switzerland and the Egyptian mission to the United Nations.

In August 1994, Moussa made his first official visit to Israel—a visit marked by tension and controversy.
Moussa has been an extremely popular political figure in Egypt due to his criticism of Israeli policies towards Gaza and the West Bank.
Amr Moussa with Giorgio Napolitano, President of Italy (Cairo, 27 October 2008).

On 11 February 2011, Al Jazeera English Online read from a Reuters report that stated Moussa was resigning from his position with the Arab League; on the day that President Mubarak resigned the presidency this furthered rumours he might make a strong bid for president when elections are announced in Egypt.
Moussa during the World Economic Forum (Davos, 2013)

quotes: After serving as Egypt's Foreign Minister from 1991 to 2001, he served as the Secretary General of the Arab League.
Moussa has been heavily involved with Egypt's foreign policy since 1958.
between 1958 and 1972 he worked in several missions, including Egypt's Embassy in Switzerland and the Egyptian mission to the United Nations.
From 1981 to 1983, Moussa was the Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations in New York,
then from 1983 to 1986 Ambassador to India.
In August 1994, Moussa made his first official visit to Israel—a visit marked by tension and controversy.
Moussa has been an extremely popular political figure in Egypt due to his criticism of Israeli policies towards Gaza and the West Bank.
On 15 May 2001, Moussa was selected as Secretary-General of the League of Arab States and took office on 1 June 2001.
On 15 May 2001, Moussa was selected as Secretary-General of the League of Arab States and took office on 1 June 2001.
On 2003, he became a member of the United Nations High Level Panel on Threats, Challenges and Change for International Peace and Security.
Amr Moussa with Giorgio Napolitano, President of Italy (Cairo, 27 October 2008).

On 2009, he signed a memorandum of understanding with the Holy See and met with Pope Benedict XVI in order to strengthen joint projects and to promote peace and dialogue on a cultural and political level.
On 13 June 2010, Moussa visited Gaza in a move to pressure Israel to lift its economic blockade over Hamas-ruled Gaza.
The visit by Moussa was the first by an official of the Arab League since the election of Hamas in 2007.
On 15 May 2011, Nabil Elaraby was elected as Secretary-General of the Arab League and succeeded Moussa on 1 July 2011.
On 15 May 2011, Nabil Elaraby was elected as Secretary-General of the Arab League and succeeded Moussa on 1 July 2011.
In 2004, an online community gathered tens of thousands of signatures petitioning for Moussa to run in the 2005 elections, but there was no response.

Critics of former-President Hosni Mubarak allege that Moussa's appointment to the office of Secretary-General of the Arab League was motivated by Mubarak's desire to remove him from the public spotlight, and so he would not compete as a candidate in the 2005 presidential elections.
Amr Moussa with Vladimir Putin (Cairo, 27 April 2005).

organizations.name: UN Security Council
quotes: Immediately after the 2010 Gaza flotilla raid, Moussa said the Arab League would go to the UN Security Council to demand the blockade be lifted.

roles.title: President
quotes: Critics of former-President Hosni Mubarak allege that Moussa's appointment to the office of Secretary-General of the Arab League was motivated by Mubarak's desire to remove him from the public spotlight, and so he would not compete as a candidate in the 2005 presidential elections.

roles.title: President of Italy
quotes: Amr Moussa with Giorgio Napolitano, President of Italy (Cairo, 27 October 2008).

roles.title: Pope
quotes: On 2009, he signed a memorandum of understanding with the Holy See and met with Pope Benedict XVI in order to strengthen joint projects and to promote peace and dialogue on a cultural and political level.
Amr Moussa with Giorgio Napolitano, President of Italy (Cairo, 27 October 2008).
On 13 June 2010, Moussa visited Gaza in a move to pressure Israel to lift its economic blockade over Hamas-ruled Gaza.
In a Doha Debate Forum televised by the BBC in 2006, Moussa was asked about his presidential hopes.
When asked in October 2009 about rumours that he might run for the presidency in 2012, Moussa did not deny his intention to run for office or rule it out, leaving the door open to speculations.
Amr Moussa with William Hague (London, 25 May 2010).
On 26 January 2011, at the Annual Horasis meeting in Zürich, Moussa shared strong views on the need for economic and political reforms in Egypt, and made it clear that he was considering a run.

On 1 February 2011, following the announcement by President Hosni Mubarak that he would not stand in the upcoming presidential elections, Moussa told CNN that he would seriously think about standing himself as a candidate in the next few weeks.

On the 8 February broadcast of Al Jazeera English's Empire, well-connected American journalist Seymour Hersh stated that Moussa was considered the U.S.'s favored 'Plan B' should Mubarak resign, 'whether he knows it or not.'

On 11 February 2011, Al Jazeera English Online read from a Reuters report that stated Moussa was resigning from his position with the Arab League; on the day that President Mubarak resigned the presidency this furthered rumours he might make a strong bid for president when elections are announced in Egypt.

roles.title: President of Egypt
quotes: When asked in October 2009 about rumours that he might run for the presidency in 2012, Moussa did not deny his intention to run for office or rule it out, leaving the door open to speculations.
He further stated to the press that the qualities required to be the President of Egypt also apply to Gamal Mubarak, son of Hosni Mubarak.

Amr Moussa with William Hague (London, 25 May 2010).
On 26 January 2011, at the Annual Horasis meeting in Zürich, Moussa shared strong views on the need for economic and political reforms in Egypt, and made it clear that he was considering a run.
On 26 January 2011, at the Annual Horasis meeting in Zürich, Moussa shared strong views on the need for economic and political reforms in Egypt, and made it clear that he was considering a run.

On 11 February 2011, Al Jazeera English Online read from a Reuters report that stated Moussa was resigning from his position with the Arab League; on the day that President Mubarak resigned the presidency this furthered rumours he might make a strong bid for president when elections are announced in Egypt.
Moussa during the World Economic Forum (Davos, 2013)
February 2011, the Egyptian daily newspaper Alwafd reported that a group of Egyptian youth met with Moussa to discuss a possible nomination for the presidential election.
Amr Moussa announced that he would be running as a presidential candidate on 1 March 2011.

organizations.name: Conference Party
quotes: After the election, he formed the Conference Party with which a number of smaller opposition parties aligned.

organizations.name: Arab League
quotes: Although credited with shaking up the Arab League's bureaucracy, Moussa has been criticized by former and current staff members of the Arab League for his management of the organization.

roles.title: presidential candidate
quotes: Amr Moussa announced that he would be running as a presidential candidate on 1 March 2011.
A poll conducted during the 2011 protests asking 'who do you think should be the next President of Egypt?' showed Moussa in the lead, with 26% of respondents naming him.
